They do ban for money, but not for the reason those saying it think.

They do it because they think they'll get more people playing their game if they remove or reform the players that harass other players, which will lead to more RP purchases.

Then how come they dont bother banning the E-mail? You can make another account on the same E-mail? If the goal is to "remove" or reform, then the players certainly arent getting removed.... 

I made a post about this when I made this new account to make a "sup only climb" and was constantly being exposed to the most toxic players in the game that had obviously been recently banned...

So Riots goal is "because they think they'll get more people playing their game if they remove or reform the players" then thats BS. All they do is piss off people who already are toxic by destroying their time/money investment, and then shuffle them into path of beginning/new players to... what... make money? drive them away? or teach them to be toxic also?

Studies show time out is the best way to discipline children, not taking their Xbox with all their games, & saves, and throwing it in the trash to teach them to be good.... though Im sure Microsoft would approve cause if they want those games back, it will cost $$$.......

Its really simple, banned players dont cease to exist... they just have to make new accounts, and if you dont think some of them spend money to replace missing champs, maybe not all but def. some... If you dont think that happens, then I dont know what to say. Overwatch will ban people for season, then they can come back and play competitive after theyve had a while to grow up. If Riot were really trying to reform people, they would go with the time out (2 week ban followed by seasonal ban).

You dont think.... come back when youre certain you cant cause you can. Im sure you can even look on these forums finding threads talking about it....

This post... two big baseless opinions formed from what you want, like, hope, believe, but nothing form observation; thats how a religion starts.

When you started that climb, an automatic smurf-detector flagged you for not being a new player and put you in a smurf queue.  Now, you play with only players who are starting extra accounts, many of which they use because their first account was banned.  Hence the toxicity.

I agree I was put in a smurf que at one point. Yes, may banned players make accounts and are very toxic, though in a different manner after the first ban often times.

I was being called and seeing others called ni**er and fa**ot in the first hand full of matches after getting out of bots. On top of that, for a while my winrate was negative cause of all the newbs getting stomped on my team so hard they couldn't be carried. Of course while Im waiting for the match to end one person on my team is still raging in all chat telling others to die in a fire for being a no life smurf. Other matches people are stomping on my team making rape jokes about how our team looks like our mothers last night begging for them to take the dick out.


The smurf detection system hadn't put me with other smurfs inside of 10 post bot match games that have a negative win rate... After around 20 matches I think it caught on, but I was appalled at how unreal the slurs and rape comments were. There was some of that when I first started, but I had forgotten how much the N-word got used.


Aside from that, the toxicity remained about at constant once Im certain I was placed in other smurfs. People started using meta tactics, and playing in a way that was starkly different at one point, but the toxicity went from slurs and rape jokes to passive aggressive and backhanded comments. More along the lines of "Well all the lanes are feeding bots, ff." Sutff like "mid afk, gg" "We don't have a jungle, just open mid" or "I cant even with this bot lane, next match." The best are when someone ask "why did you x" and someone takes the bait and then they start typing a novel of crap at them. I mean novel too. They would just spew endlessly, trying to get the person riled up so they would say "fuck off" or call them a "dumbass" or something so they could report them.

See one problem with Riots ban system is it encourages trolls to try and bait other people into a response that can get them punished. People see troll baiters all the time, and its because of the perma bans people want to make others suffer. So this system also brings in trolls who are "playing league" but their real game is getting others punished. If perma bans exist, those trolls will always be in the game trying to bait people. They would never truly go away, but if their sense of impact wanes they may find somewhere else to troll.

So bans not only fail to remove banned players from the game, they also give a tool for trolls to fish for victims.

> [{quoted}](name=Illabethe,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=EWFKK2sj,comment-id=000100000000000000000001,timestamp=2018-10-09T14:45:32.005+0000)

Well first of all, Riot estimates player skill early on and bumps those it identifies as smurfs, so when you smurf, it's more likely for you to run into other smurfs than a new player.  That said, I'd question the 4 out of 5 number.

But even if all that were true, what still makes absolutely no sense is the assertion that Riot bans players to make more money off the players they ban.  Literally no sense whatsoever.  For that to be true, all of the following would have to be true:

1. Players are more likely to spend money on a fresh account than on an account they've had for years and already spent money on.
2. Riot has identified as a target for sales growth the .006% of players they actually ban.
3. The potential paying customers put off by toxic behavior do not far outweigh the spending potential of the toxic players.

If you don't agree with the above 3 assumptions, then the assertion that Riot bans players to make more money off of them makes absolutely no sense.

My logic train is that if someone who wants to play MOBA style games will continue to play MOBA style games. If someone who wants to play League of Legends is banned, they will not cease playing the game.

I dont know about ALL players, making that kind of assumption would be foolish.

I do know about basic human behavior and desires. If they want to play the game, an account being banned wont stop them from playing. Not sure why you think it would. If banning people cured toxicity, then based on a game with millions of players Riot would have weeded out all the toxic people interested in MOBAs by now and the game wouldnt have any toxic people in it anymore cause they get banned and dont come back hurr durr...

I cant say how many make a new account after being banned, do they? YES, undoubtedly, you can take a trip through player behavior with people talking about how they were banned and realized how toxic they were, and consider themselves reformed... they obviously made new accounts. There are plenty of those, and probably thousands more that do the same but dont write on the forums about it.

Dose Riot make twice as much money for selling the same skin to a banned player on a new account? YES, they do.

Riots ban stance does two things, first, to those not looking very closely it looks like theyre cracking down on poor player behavior that makes some people think "Riot is protecting me for trolls and ragers!" Second, It makes some people who get banned potentialy buy stuff twice. If they make a new account and dont buy anything, who cares they already got their money. If theyve never spent a dime on the game who cares, they dont spend money. Win/win for Riot. Makes people stay off their back cause theyre "doing something" and sometimes makes them money twice.

So my "claim" is that banning doesnt remove banned players from the game (provided they make the effort to make a user name and password), and their bans stand to make them money by selling to people twice (provided the player wishes to replace champs and skins they desire).... thats my stance, I tried to explain it for you multiple ways so you could understand.

First of all, if you aren't claiming that ALL permanently banned players come back on new accounts, then you are admitting that the current process does indeed reduce toxicity, as there are fewer toxic players than there would be if said players were not being permanently banned.

Second of all, can you think of any other business, gaming or otherwise where you would believe that the act of telling patrons their business is unwelcome would be considered a solid business strategy?  If a movie theater kept taking your money and then kicking you out halfway through the show, would you keep going to that movie theater?  You still like movies right?  If a bar kept taking your money and kicking you out before you finished your drink, would you keep going to that bar?  You still like to drink right?  If a taxi service kept dropping you off halfway to your destination and telling you to fuck off, would you keep using that taxi service?  You still have places to go right?

Any salesperson, any marketing person, anyone with any experience at all in the field will tell you that it is much easier and much more lucrative to keep an existing customer than it is to land a new one.  This is why every brand from lowly mom-and-pop restaurants to huge chains like Starbucks, and across industries from hotels to airlines to retail stores ALL have loyalty programs designed to keep customers coming back.  These companies are investing huge amounts of money to make sure they KEEP their customers.  When a company tells you "Go away, we don't want your business," it's pretty safe to assume **they don't want your business**.

And finally, for those players that do decide return AND spend more money on the game, do you think they will continue to be toxic?  If there was a big red button on the League client that would permanently delete your account and you accidentally pressed it once, do you think if you created a new account you would ever press that button again?

Am I going to argue that no one ever comes back and spends money?  No, that's the hazard of absolutes.  However, anyone with common sense can understand that a business model that involves sending customers away in hopes that they'll come back and purchase more goods is ludicrous, and that those who do decide to come back and spend more money are much less likely to be toxic than if they had never lost their accounts in the first place.

>First of all, if you aren't claiming that ALL permanently banned players come back on new accounts, then you are admitting that the current process does indeed reduce toxicity

No....? I dont know how many make accounts after being banned, I know some do, I dont know that they all do. Its possible that they all do, not knowing if they all do dosnt mean I admit it reduces toxicity (and by reduce you are saying REMOVES toxic players)... it means I admit to not knowing how many people make new accounts after being banned. Its somewhere between 1-100% of people. Just because I cant say its 100% (because it could be, I DONT KNOW) doesnt mean I have say its therefore removed ANYONE.... Not sure how you arrived at that nonsense, but it is indeed a fallacy to say I admitted anything of the kind.

Remember earlier when I said what causes religions? Youve got talent, cause this is the typical "You cant prove God doesnt exist, so therefore he MUST exist!" Cant prove all banned players make new accounts, therefore they dont!"

>Second of all, can you think of any other business, gaming or otherwise where you would believe that the act of telling patrons their business is unwelcome would be considered a solid business strategy?

I can think of businesses that treat their customers like trash and carry on in a "if you want this service you will deal with us" manner. Have you ever dealt with the airlines? They double book, telling people who show up for their flight they cant go on it cause they sold the seat twice... and if you dont like it, you can just suck it, hell you can walk to where youre going. Just like how if Riot bans someone, and they still want to play... they can just suck it (up an make a new account). League of Legends is the only League of Legends, so if a player wants to fly they... oh, I mean play League, they will deal with their treatment of being double booked... I mean being banned. So yeah... I can think of other businesses that do that, and GAMING... YES, RIOT BANS PEOPLE... and they make new accounts; think we covered that.

>Any salesperson, any marketing person, anyone with any experience at all in the field will tell you that it is much easier and much more lucrative to keep an existing customer 

This would be an actual point, if there was another League of Legends.... Its isnt a car rental service, or a meal delivery plan, or a taxi company. Its ONE game. If you want that ONE thing that their is ONE of, you can only get that ONE thing from ONE place. Therefore, if a person wants that thing, they will try to get it. Ban... or no. I dont think people are considering the "feelings" of draconian punishment method when making a new account.

>it's pretty safe to assume they don't want your business.

Irrelevant if the PLAYER makes a new account, and wants to give them money... why even bother typing this. Its pointless, people make new accounts after being banned, its a fact regardless of if Riot wants them to.

>And finally, for those players that do decide return AND spend more money on the game, do you think they will continue to be toxic? If there was a big red button on the League client that would permanently delete your account and you accidentally pressed it once, do you think if you created a new account you would ever press that button again?

Dont ask me to explain self destructive human behavior, why does anyone do anything that they know is bad for them? Brain damage, addiction, stubbornness, inebriation, stupidity. 

Here you will see some agreement from me that "punishment" can work to change behavior. Banning people for the season, or 3 months, would serve much the same purpose of teaching people the lesson that this point of yours is trying to make... with one exception. Time out ends, and people dont have to buy stuff twice. I agree Riot "punishes" people to affect behavior, but they BAN permanently because people DO come back, and when they do they HAVE TO spend money if they want their champs/skins back in short order.

Pick an arbitrary long duration, 1 year. If people had accounts suspended for 1 year.... they would have time to think about what theyve done, time to physically, and emotionally mature, and it would be a significant removal period. People could come back, new attitude, avoid the same mistakes that got them kicked out for a year, it would do all the things bans do... except make people buy stuff twice... unless they bought some things on the account they made while waiting to play on their original.

>a business model that involves sending customers away in hopes that they'll come back and purchase more goods is ludicrous

Thats not the business model, never said it was, youre inferring that, trying to argue cause you dont have anything better to do or you just cant get what Im saying.

The business model is a a game where they give an slightly unfair playing field of only having a few champions slowly trickle in, but you can buy them to increase your composition/counter pick options, and also sell cosmetics, while occasionally selling cosmetics twice to a small % of players as a little extra.

Like I said, Riot "punishes" to affect player behavior. Extreme offenders should get some kind of punishment, consistent or violent threats should get some kind of ban I should think, just not perma bans. I dont think perma bans do anything productive... cept maybe in corporate eyes.

It's funny that you mention airlines.  I've been on plenty of flights.  In fact, last year alone I flew 140,000 miles.  I will tell you that #1, airlines go out of their way to retain customers, especially high paying customers, and #2 that situation you just described does not happen the way you described it.
